column2: Saint John Baptiste is known best for baptisting Christ, and for being the praton Saint of old Quebec. Although this feat may seem rather remote and disconnected from the modern age, Saint John The Baptist is nonetheless one of the most popular saints in all of Christendom, and his feast day is considered a major holiday in most of Old Quebec.
the traditional Saint John Baptiste Day festivities begin.

Nobody remembers why Saint John Baptiste came to be so well-regarded in Old Quebec, but his feast day draws large crowds each year. Saint John Baptiste Day is traditionally celebrated with a joyous procession through the streets followed by a series of raucous nighttime feasts and bonfires.
I can't wait to see the bards...

The annual Saint John Baptiste Day procession has begun. Your capital's streets are filled with pilgrims from across the land, and the air is filled with the sounds of cheers and ancient ballads. Many of the pilgrims make a large show of waving the Carillon Sacred Heart Flag. The Banner that depicts the Sacred-Heart of Christ along with the flag of old Quebec.

Night has fallen, and the procession has come to an end. The people are now heading to local taverns for the start of the second half of the celebration, the feasts. These "feasts" usually devolve into drunken, hedonistic revelry, so more religious [Root.Religon.GetName]s frown on them. However, they are still an integral part of the celebrations for most.
I think I'll pass this year.
You get a little carried away with your drink...
Saint John Baptiste Day comes to an end.

You wake up in an alleyway, with the sun shining overhead and your head pounding in pain. Your memory slowly begins to return to you. You went to a tavern last night after the Saint John Baptiste Day procession. Then you went to another tavern... and another tavern... You wince in pain after glancing up at the sky. You should probably get some rest.

You wake up in an alleyway, with the sun shining overhead and your entire body aching in pain. Your memory slowly begins to return to you. Someone at the tavern started a fight with you... or perhaps you started a fight with them? In any case, the entire tavern ended up joining the melee, and now you're paying the price...
I don't think I can walk this off...

You wake up in your bed, feeling tired yet oddly happy. Your memory begins to return to you. You had a great time at the tavern! You sang many ballads, told a few somewhat embellished stories, and were generally the center of attention all night. And the best part? You don't even have a hangover!
I can't wait for next year!

You wake up in an unfamiliar bed, in an unfamiliar room... next to an unfamiliar person. As you struggle to remember what you did last night, you hear a crude-sounding, alcohol-scented voice from the other side of the bed. "Morning there, [Root.GetLadLass]. You wanna go again? I haven't had a tumble that good in ages, and that's really saying something."

The child you have had with the [Root.GetManWomanOpp] you met on Saint John Baptiste Day seems to possess an unusually high level of strength and intelligence. Perhaps your encounter wasn't as ill-advised as you thought.
I am proud of my child.
Though not official Mounties, these cavalrymen train in the ancient traditions and tactics of the Mounties.
I shall seek to study the word of God.

Throughout history various Monarchs of the Anglican Church have sought to leave their mark on the Church and realm. In recent centuries it has become common for Kings to issue an Edict of Uniformity to enforce one Tradition in their realms - often at the risk of revolt or even civil war.

Throughout history various Monarchs of the Anglican Church have sought to leave their mark on the Church and realm. In recent centuries it has become common for Kings to issue an Edict of Uniformity to enforce one Tradition in their realms - often at the risk of revolt or even civil war.

Throughout all the realm in every inn, church and fortress agents of [From.GetTitledName] annouce the issuing of the Edict of Uniformity. All Anglicans of the realm are to follow the holy traditions of [From.GetTitledName], and [From.GetHerHis] vassals are expected to carry it out. Whether their vassals will or not remains to be seen...
The other Traditions are in error, I shall issue an Edict of Uniformity.
Let my reign be known for tolerance, I shall issue an Edict of Tolerance!
This is not a good time. We can leave such decisions for later...
This is an acceptable development, I accept.
Reluctantly accepts the Edict of Uniformity
This ruler has issued an Edict of Uniformity to try forcing his tradition of Anglicanism on the realm.
This ruler has issued an Edict of Tolerance, pleasing many vassals.
For centuries going back before the Deluge, Anglicans bishops have been chosen by their liege lords.

An ancient tradition among the Anglican church, the Episcopal Conference is a regularly held gathering of clergy to discuss various matters. This gathering is most beloved by those of the Broad Tradition.
Let us join the clergy in such a gathering!

A tradition among some Anglicans especially of the broad rite was to always seek to be ecumenical with other Christians such as through inviting them to Conferences. This however tends to anger zealots seeing it as a corruption of the faith.

This Ruler has sought to be seen welcoming to all those of the Anglican faithful, though there is difference in belief and practice among the branches. This ruler has sought to be welcoming and unitive to all the faithful.
This ruler has insulted many of the Anglican faithful, deeming only men and clergy of his tradition as able to come to his conference. Only zealots of his tradition approve of these actions.

Among those of the Broad Tradition it is a popular tradition for local rulers to host episcopal conferences, the question remains tho whom shall be invited? Only those who follow the Broad traditions? All fellow Anglicans or allow invitations be sent to all Christians of note in your realm?
Let us invite all Christians to attend this conference.
Let us invite all clergy and lords of the Anglican faithful.
If they do not worship the same as me, I will not tolerant them.

You have received an invitation from your liege to attend an episcopal conference, a common tradition among broad anglican lords is to take part in and host local conferences. Shall you accept the invitation?
I would be honored to attend.
[From.GetTitledName] has refused to come to the conference. However clergy from [From.GetHerHis] domain have happily accepted invitations they have recieved.

As guests pour into the court, your [Root.GetMyLordSpiritualName] begins the conference, being sure to honor you and your piety for hosting this Conference. You gain fame and piety for treating the clergy as you have.
The Episcopal Conference was run without much issue, your vassals and clergy got to brush shoulders with eachother and you. Hopefully this shall improve relations in the Church.
The Episcopal Conference was run without much issue, your fellow vassals and clergy got to brush shoulders with eachother and your liege. Hopefully this shall improve relations in the Church.
It was certainly interesting interacting with these sorts of Christians.
It was a pleausre to converse with fellow Anglicans, our differences aside.
Exiled to the wilderness never to return...
Exiled to the wilderness never to return...

Anglo Catholicism originates from the Anglican Church and the opinion of some Anglicans that their church is not simply another Protestant denomination but a branch of the historical Christian Church tracing its lineage more to Rome than London. This theological divide within the church ruptured after the Deluge due to opposition to the Anglican Communion’s attempt to form a broad tent with other Protestants. These Anglo Catholics rejected the Anglicans, but they also felt revulsion towards the grasping Mother Superior of the Ursulines and the self-styled Papacy further south. Due to these factors, the Anglos Catholics instead rallied around their newly-formed Primate of Canada, and they now strive to preserve their own historical apostolic succession of priests and bishops, and thus the Catholic sacraments.
This ruler was annointed by the Primate himself
